sigma 70 200 lens.title: Sigma 70-200mm f/2.8 DG OS HSM 'Sports' lens review
sigma 70 200 lens.description: This large and heavy alternative to Canon and Nikon's 70-200's has a good reputation and is certainly more affordable. Let's see ...
sigma 70 200 lens.transcript: [Music] howdy again everyone and here is a lens that somehow i didn't end up testing for whatever reason the sigma 70 to 200 millimeter f 2.8 dg os hsm sports a few people have been requesting a review of this one so i got in touch with sigma uk who kindly loaned a copy to me for a couple of weeks for testing many thanks to them i took it on a brief little sojourn to the east coast of england for a week as well as topping off at cardiff bay on the way home and i was delighted with the sample pictures i took it's been around for a few years now being first released in 2018 and it's designed for digital slr cameras although of course it can also be mounted onto mirrorless cameras if you have the correct adapter it's not a cheap lens by any means it's about one thousand one hundred and eighty pounds in the uk or about fifteen hundred dollars in the us still that undercuts the price of canon's ef equivalent by about six hundred dollars and nikon's afs equivalent lens by about nine hundred dollars so if this sigma competitor is any good it could save you a lot of money and a 70-200 millimeter f 2.8 is probably the most important professional model of camera lens available today it's a real bread and butter lens for event photographers sports and reportage photographers and portraits and wedding photographers but it could also be used for landscape work and video making well you get the idea it is versatile and particularly when you zoom into 200 millimeter it can give you some very deeply out of focus backgrounds when it comes to build quality this lens is big and tough not to mention surprisingly weighty coming in at 1.8 kilograms or nearly four pounds that is notably more heavy than canon's ef mount 70 to 200 millimeter f 2.8 lenses which weigh nearly a pound less and canon's rf mount 70 to 200 millimeter f 2.8 weighs just over half as much so one of the main prices you'll have to pay with this sigma lens is portability it really is quite weighty putting that aside though this thing sure is tough it has weather sealing throughout including a ceiling gasket at the rear lens mount it has a heavy duty and well designed metal tripod collar although i do wish it were removable to save a bit on weight when it's not needed then you get a number of controls for auto focus and image stabilization let's look at stabilization first or os as sigma call it here is some footage with it turned off and now turned on to mode one which i found to be the most effective as you can see it's making a very nice difference indeed even at 200 millimeter your image is pretty steady although video makers might still wish to use a tripod for best results and if you have a sigma usb dock the lenses image stabilization and parts of its autofocus are customizable the rubberized focus ring works smoothly but a little heavily as this is an older lens it's physically connected to the focus mechanism not electronically connected and as a result it works quite precisely and linearly as you can see here the lens exhibits quite a bit of focus breathing zooming in quite a lot as you focus more closely no matter what focal length you're shooting at and that will annoy video makers some good news though is that the lens auto focus motor is very fast as you can see here and mostly accurate the lenses zoom ring is also rubberized and works nice and smoothly too the very end of the lens barrel is also rubberized and that's always a nice touch to me as it reduces the chances of the whole thing cracking open if you accidentally hit it against a hard surface the lens comes with one of sigma's excellent carry bags and a deep high quality lens hood which is not pictured here its filter size is a larger than usual 82 millimeters wide overall well it's fantastic build quality here but the thing is a bit heavy all right let's look at image quality can this sigma lens be competitively sharp i'll be testing it adapted onto my canon eos r5 with its challenging full frame 45 megapixel sensor in camera corrections are turned on we'll start at 70 millimeter and f 2.8 right away in the middle we see excellent sharpness and contrast the corners look virtually as sharp well a good start stop down to f4 for just a minuscule improvement there the lens tastes the sharp down to f11 but f16 looks a little softer due to the effects of diffraction let's zoom in halfway to 135 millimeter the middle of the image at f 2.8 is notably softer than at 70 millimeter but still reasonably sharp corner image quality looks about the same stop down to f4 though for excellent image quality to re-emerge from the corners and back to the middle again the image stays this sharp down to f11 and finally let's zoom all the way into 200 millimeter at f 2.8 the excellent sharpness we originally saw in the middle is thankfully back image quality over in the corners is noticeably softer than the middle but still fairly good at f4 the corners look about the same but stop down to f 5.6 or f 8 to see that excellent sharpness re-emerging overall this lens is sharp most of the time at most apertures in most areas of the image there was a little bump at 135 millimeter and f 2.8 and the corners at 200 millimeter are not razor sharp but very few people in their right mind would seriously complain because on a whole there's loads of resolution to be seen here and very good contrast all right let's turn off those in the camera corrections and take a look at distortion and vignetting at 70 millimeter we see only negligible barrel distortion here and a little darkness around the corners at f 2.8 stop down to f4 or 5.6 for those corners to brighten zoom into 200 millimeter and we are treated some moderately strong pincushion distortion at f 2.8 corners are pretty dark here stop down to f4 and we quickly see much more brightness it's an average performance for distortion and vignetting there thankfully no nasty surprises though the lenses minimum focus distance is 1.2 meters so you can get fairly close to smaller subjects at 200 millimeter at f 2.8 close-up image quality is rather soft unfortunately with blue color fringing stop down to f4 for an improvement and at 5.6 and especially f8 the image becomes very sharp again let's see how the lens works against bright light it's just an okay performance here we see some notable but not serious flaring at wider angles zoom in and it gets worse so just an average performance here i don't really test telephoto lenses for coma levels although perhaps i might do one day but i was curious about this thing's sun stars stopped under f8 and sun stars are just about beginning to form themselves here at f-16 they're looking pretty nice and at f 18 they look quite strong as you can see next bokeh for the past 10 years or so it doesn't seem to have been a problem for 70 to 200 millimeter lenses to get you some really smooth quality bokeh and this lens thankfully is no exception in all my test pictures including extra ones that didn't make it into this review this thing's out of focus backgrounds look gorgeous about as smooth and pleasing as barry white's voice anyone still listen to barry white anyway related debaca comes longitudinal chromatic aberration here's another little weak spot it's rather strong at f 2.8 with some false colors clearly emerging they remain at f4 are reduced though at 5.6 and at f 8 they are largely gone so overall the sigma 70 to 200 millimeter f 2.8 support is an excellent lens with one or two little weak points here and there its build quality is excellent it's auto focus and image stabilization very good most of all it's an impressively sharp lens with pretty gorgeously soft looking bokeh and really for a lens like this those are the key considerations for any professional photographer there are a few small niggles which for the price you're paying for the lens do prevent it from getting my highest recommendation though for example it's heavy weight it's focus breathing it's slightly weak close-up image quality and longitudinal chromatic aberration but generally speaking the lens is very sharp works very well and its price is quite acceptable if you can't quite afford an official canon on nikon 70 to 200 millimeter f 2.8 lens then this one from sigma will suit you really nicely saving you lots of money and so it still comes recommended [Music] you know what maybe i complain about heavy lenses too much i really need to work out much much more perhaps i should welcome the challenge and see it as an opportunity to build up my biceps i'm sure my wife would appreciate it anyway what definitely does not build up my biceps is sitting in my office editing exclusive videos for my patreon supporters but i'm gonna do it anyway because i really appreciate their generosity in keeping this channel going to do your bit and to get special videos and other bonus content take a look in the description below and join the gang take care and god bless everyone

sigma 70 200 lens.title: Sigma 70-200mm f/2.8 DG DN Sport Review: It's FINALLY here!
sigma 70 200 lens.description: After years of waiting, Sigma has finally completed its trio of f/2.8 zooms for full frame mirrorless with the 70-200mm f/2.8 DG DN ...
sigma 70 200 lens.transcript: hey Chris we got a new Sigma lens we got a sigma 1424 oh good so I guess that means the 7200 is coming next 90 mm 2.8 oh okay but this 7200 is coming soon right we got a 1628 2.8 that's what they came out with next 20 mm F2 huh 20 mm f1.4 wait what 17 mm F4 that's an odd Choice Chris it finally happened the Sigma 70 to 200 is here you're kidding me welcome back pet pixel viewers it is Chris Nichols here and I think as we adroitly Illustrated there it has been a bit of a weight for this lens but we finally have it the brand new segma 70 to2 200 f2.8 DG DN for mirrorless Sony e- Mount and L Mount and why this is a big deal is because in this time that we've been waiting of course we've had Sony I mean 7200 G Master version one and version 2 Tamron 70 to 180 version one and then G2 Panasonic have a 7200 f2.8 for the El Mount but we have not seen anything from Sigma since the SLR days the long weight is finally over here we go let's take a look at [Music] it [Music] so the first issue that I want to address is the first thing that I noticed about the sigma 7200 2.8 when I first picked it up and that's just that it's quite heavy so to give you guys context the sigma 702 200f 2.8 dgn we're looking at 1350 G roughly okay and that's you know just under a plan and a half but if I compare that to then this Sony GM 7200 2.8 version 2 that lens is only 1,45 G I mean just over a planet I mean it's noticeably lighter and then I compare that to the Tamron g270 to 180 f2.8 that I just recently played with that thing's 855 gram so substantially lighter and so when I picked this up I really noticed it that being said when we take a look at this versus the Panasonic L Mount 70 to 200f 2.8 that lens is still over 1500 G so I think maybe what Sigma is trying to do is not necessarily get lighter than the e-mount but absolutely try to again under what the Panasonic 7200 offers for weight okay so let's talk about the rest of the handling on the sigma 7200 starting at the front here and working our way back the first thing thing I notice here is the hood it's not a one button quick release press it's just a screw lock and twist I don't mind that I mean I can position it wherever I want and it is secure I also like that the Hood's got this rubberized material on the front when I put the lens down and stuff it just like that it doesn't wear at the hood oddly enough though when it is mounted you'll notice that it goes over the zoom ring a bit so I'm constantly thinking like oh is my hood reversed or not it's not I can assure you otherwise we have a 77 mm filter thread here in the front Okay so next thing we have is the zoom ring here and and with the hood in the way there I do like that at least it stops my fingers naturally if I'm moving up to find the zoom ring but I also find because the hood the zoom ring is somewhat narrow there to grab but it works just fine custom buttons here and you can customize those for a couple functions and then choose to switch that here right on the side of the lens then I've got my manual focus ring and interestingly enough we do have an actual aperture ring on here it's got nice solid click stops I can lock it into auto mode if I want and I can also declick that apertur ring if I want to be smooth and silent now something that I complained about on the Tamron 70 to 180 G2 was its lack of button controls it had a very simplified structure here and I far prefer having something like this on the sigma I like having my classic autofocus manual focus switch Focus limiter I like that the tripod color has the 90° Dayton clicks I always enjoy that and it does have Dov tail cut for ARCA Swift style tripod heads that's a nice bonus as well this lens is fully weather sealed and it absolutely feels solid I mean it's metal construction it's rugged everything tight so yes the sigma 7200 f2.8 is a heavy lens and heavier than I would want it to be honestly but I don't feel like I'm missing out anything that I would normally appreciate on a professional 2.8 telephoto lens so when it comes to autofocusing Sigma using their twin H high-speed linear actuators just like Tamron would use their twin linear voice coil Motors just like Sony would use their twin XD linear motor the fact is all these modern professional lenses have fast linear actuators and and on the sigma 7200 I'm finding again very quick response from things that are close minimum focusing distance to infinity and back so Snappy ideal for sports street photography any sort of portraiture and journalism work you might want to do now the ton 70 to 1880 G2 they were advertising that at 70 mm you could get very close to your subject like 11 in away and do some pseudo macro kind of stuff and I only bring it up because I want to see what's the sigma 7200 like in comparison well this certainly has more working distance you get your best macro at 200 mm not 70 mm your working distance is just under 40 in however we're getting over 1 to five life- siiz reproduction for macro so the occasional shot where you want to simplify your composition and have something closeup kind of stand up for the background sure but I would not call it a macro lens in any way shape or form and if you're trying to get shots of portraits where you just want the eyes or something you're going to have to crop bouquet time Sigma 7200 2.8 looks like it has beautiful bouquet specular highlights as you can see here slight soap bubble effect but no onion rings whatsoever and I'm getting nice transitions from INF Focus to autofocus areas there's definitely distinct cat ey effect at f2.8 but again I don't really mind that with the telephoto lens especially something for portraits where you can in some cases use those specular highlights to give a cool swirly effect stop down things do get nice and round we're not noticing any weird polygonal shapes although even stopped down to f4.5 I'm still getting a fair amount of that cat ietting in the corner Loca time let's talk about longitudinal chromatic aberration this is where shallow depth the field out of focus areas will pick up a color cast usually like a green magenta split it's very hard to get rid of impost so you don't want it fortunately Sigma professional lenses generally don't suffer from Loca and it's the same thing here you can see that any loc is incredibly minimal we're not really getting those Color cast so no issues to worry about in post so you may or may have noticed it's been an ugly cloudy day all day today but look the sun's just broken out you can see it on my face right now so time to talk about flar as we got some test shots here so you know sigas have always been really good at controlling flare this lens seems to be no exception shooting wide open at f2.8 you can see we're not really losing any contrast it's still really good stopping the lens down we get some ghost slightly but very unobtrusive so classic Sigma excellent control when shooting towards bright light sources all right let's talk about the sigma 7200 in terms of its video capabilities cuz first off we've got some really nice benefits as I've said before the manual focus ring smooth well dampened we also have an aperture ring which is great and we can declick that these are all big benefits for video Shooters but most importantly does this lens breathe well as you can see here in the example no not really at all now the fact that this lens basically has no breathing issues is less important for El Mount because the competition the Panasonic 7200 is also well corrected but this is very handy to have in Sony e-mount because typically the lenses you you'll find the Sony G Masters the Tamron 7180 they do have a little bit of breathing that takes place so this now gives you an option if you absolutely don't want any at all all right so it's time to find out does the sigma 7200 even sharp bro that makes that's how kids talk right so sharpness wise let's do our usual thing looking at the test chart here we're going to start at 70 mm in the center shooting wide open at f2.8 Fantastic detail very impressed I honestly didn't notice really any improvements stopping down to f5.6 uh where I did notice Improvement was in the corners you can see her 70 mm f2.8 Corners are still decent but by stopping down we got a little bit more contrast and a little bit more sharpness now take a look at 200 mm pretty similar story Center at f2.8 decent detail here I did notice that stopping down gave me a little Improvement in sharpness contrast was already good and same story for the corners f2.8 at 200 mm little bit soft not bad at all but stopping down you do notice an improvement okay so time to take a look at how the sigma 72 2.8 pairs against its contemporaries and I don't mean Sigma contemporary lenses it's a very confusing naming structure I mean contemporary lenses from like Sony and you know Panasonic and Tamron anyways so here's what I would say I mean first off no lens really does compare and sharpness to the Sony G Master version 2 I would say that is still going to be the most expensive but optically best lens we're going to see at 7200 as far as sharpness goes but I would say this is very comparable to the Tamron uh especially at 70 mm the Tamron does seem to me to be just a hair sharper at 180 mm than this is at 200 mm that being said I would still happily shoot the sigma 7200 wide open throughout its range I think you're still going to get professional results okay but what about an LM Mount this lens versus the Panasonic 702 2.8 well we never shot the 70 to 200 2.8 Panasonic on test charts and certainly not the same test charts we use today so it wouldn't quite be fair that way however I do remember the Panasonic 7200 2.8 being a good lens and a sharp lens absolutely but a subst stantially more expensive lens than the sigma if it is sharper than this lens I don't think it's necessarily worth the extra cost and honestly I think the sigma is sharper anyways which makes this definitely the more practical choice so what I buy this lens let's talk about L Mount first because compared to the Panasonic 702 2.8 this is optically a fantastic lens with no breathing it's got great controls it is heavy but lighter than the Panasonic 70 22.8 and it's far less money so yes absolutely I think if you're looking for for an L Mount 7200 2.8 this is the right way to go but what about versus other Sony ount options I know I've been comparing this Sigma against the Tamron 70 180 G2 a lot and that's because well of course they're both third party options for Sony e-mount but they're also very similar pricing I will say that having used this all day the only thing about the handling that still kind of rubs me the wrong way is the zoom ring I still find it's weird with the hood there it feels strange I don't know is I'm not getting used to it but I do really like all of the extra controls on this Sigma that's something I don't like about the Tamron that being said I feel like the Tamron I'm giving up 20 mm in the long range but I'm gaining a little bit better Optical sharpness it's basically the same kind of bouquet same kind of flare resistance and Optical performance but it's way smaller and it's way lighter and it's still well built and rugged I do find that I tend to be more biased towards compact gear I like lighter weight stuff that's easier to carry around but I really think the Tamron for me is probably the better choice when it comes to the Sony GM of course that's going to be a big jump up in price but it does dominate optically in pretty much every way shape and form and on top of that remember that both the tamon and the sigma especially you're using more of the faster Sony sports related cameras will be cap at shooting 15 frames per second with continuous autofocus going so that might be a consideration as well but no matter how you look at it although we've been waiting a long time for this lens it is finally here and I think sigma's done a great job delivering us a fantastic professional lens for a very good price no matter how you slice it leave your comments below please let us know what you think we always like that feedback listen to our podcast it's on the exact same channel or you can listen to it on all your favorite podcasting apps it's just a petapixel podcast we'd love to see you there as well click that notification Bell subscribe give the channel a like we always appreciate that support too we'll see you soon with more episodes on [Applause] P

sigma 70 200 lens.title: FINALLY! Sigma 70-200mm F2.8 for Sony Hands on Preview
sigma 70 200 lens.description: MY COLOR GRADING PRESETS: http://www.manuelortizphoto.com/presets THE MANNY ORTIZ BEAUTY DISH: ...
sigma 70 200 lens.transcript: this is a lens that so many Sony users have been waiting for and it's only $1,500 and you're getting damn near G Master performance now before we get started this video is brought to you by my color grading presets for Lightroom um I just released a new set of color grading presets that are specifically for Studio portraits now whether you want to make the skin pop or you want to just reduce those pesky orange undertones that come with using artificial light these are going to be perfect for you check it out link will be in the description when I first held this lens in my hand the thing that stood out to me first was how they designed the zoom ring instead of it being more in the middle like the Sony it's at the end of the barrel and you have to turn it the opposite direction so that on the sigma you're turning it counterclockwise to zoom which when you think of it it actually makes sense if you're using this lens with the tripod collar at the bottom the zooming being at the end of the lens lens allows me to access it without any obstruction and having and being able to turn it counterclockwise makes sense if I'm holding it with my left hand because again it's not my the the tripod collar is not getting in the way so I get that my only gripe is because it's at the end of the barrel and the zoom ring is on the stiffer side zooming the lens in the hand causes me to be a little bit more shaky when I am doing that compared to the Sony but that's not really a big deal now I didn't get a chance to really like test this lens shooting what I normally do and shoot portraits but I did take some photos of some doggies at the dog park testing out the image quality and autofocus now this 70 to 20000 has a floating Focus mechanism just like the Sony which means that you're getting extremely fast autofocus and doing a couple tests in the studio like the lens pretty much focused like instantly with no no hesitation just like the Sony my hit rate shooting the dogs using the A1 at 30 frames per second it was pretty solid I I will say this the one advantage that I feel the Sony has with autofocus is when you're rack zooming so the Sony does a better job maintaining autofocus when I'm taking pictures and at the same time I'm rack zooming the lens the sigma struggled a little bit there now what about image quality comparing the images I can say that there was not much of a difference between the two like the in terms of sharpness they look identical background blur they both have 11 aperture blades they look really similar they look really good if you were to show me these images without telling me what lens I used I I would have guessed that they were shot with a prime lens because they it is that good Focus breathing is pretty much non-existent on either of these lenses my Sony A1 does not have Focus breathing compensation yet cuz it's coming soon but it doesn't matter because whether I have the Sony or the sigma on here the sigma has virtually zero Focus breathing it's very impressive now what about lens construction the Sigma 70 to 200 has 20 elements in 15 groups six lld exclusive low dispersion elements two sld exclusive low dispersion ele no three yeah oh damn I'm the teleprompt is going too fast let's try this again what about lens construction the Sigma 70 to 200 has 20 elements in 15 groups six lld exclusive low dispersion elements two sld exclusive low dispersion elements three aspherical elements 11 aperture blades and a 77 mm filter thread same as the Sony and it weighs 13 three 1,335 grams now it is about 300 grams heavier than the GM version 2 and about 100 grams lighter than the version one on the Sigma 70 to 200 we have a lot of switches and buttons so here we have a focus ammf switch we have a range limiter switch an optical stabilization switch a custom switch we have an aperture ring with the click on and off and we have a aperture lock ring on the other side along with three customizable buttons along the zoom ring it's also a slightly taller lens than the G Master but not by much now up until this point Sony users haven't had many options when it came to telephoto zoom lenses which is weird because for some focal links we have like five different options you know the only other option out there was the is the tamarra 70 to 180 um now we have a solid alternative a direct alternative to the 70 to 200 for a lot less money I'm talking $1200 less and the teleprompt is going too fast again with the sigma now we have a solid alternative to the 70 to 200 g Master for a lot less money like $1,200 less and you're getting very comparable results and performance I think this is really impressive and I think this lens is going to sell really well all right well it's the day before the launch and I now have to edit this video for tomorrow and I'm literally I was literally a walking zombie today all righty here we go
